Let’s Celebrate a Day of Kindness
The 143rd Day of the year is declared a statewide day of kindness as "1-4-3 Day" to honor the late Mister Fred Rogers.
Pennsylvania is celebrating the second annual 1-4-3 Day. Mister Rogers would often use the number "1-4-3" as a way of saying I love you on his show Mister Roger's Neighborhood. Hence, the reason this Day of Kindness is celebrated on the 143rd day of the year!

“This year’s Day of Kindness has even more significance as we look at the roles health care providers and first responders are playing daily as we deal with COVID-19,” said Dr. Michael Loughead, Superintendent of Hampton Township School District.

Fred Rogers once said, “When I was a boy and I would see scary things in the news, my mother would say to me, ‘Look for the helpers. You will always find people who are helping.’ “
Today, we encourage you to celebrate the helpers by sharing kindness and compassion with everyone.

Students are encouraged to express their gratitude to their teachers in any of these ways, as simply or as creatively as they like from the comfort and safety of their home.
Students opting to “sing it” can easily use the tune of “Happy Birthday” and substitute “Happy Teacher Appreciation Week.” Or, they can let their musical creativity run wild.

Budding and skilled artists can use chalk, crayons or whatever is handy.
All submissions will be posted on our District’s social media and shared with our teachers.

All you need to do is email your student’s submission to Communications@HT-SD.ORG any time this week or text it to 215-808-3513. Be sure to include your student’s name, school, grade and, if you wish, the teacher they are thanking.

Curb side pick-up time is from 11:30 AM until 1:00 PM, Monday through Friday. We may adjust the time for pick up as we evaluate the needs of our families.

Thank you to our food service staff and the Metz team for helping us continue this valuable program during this unprecedented situation!

Hampton students in 5th and 6th grade participated in CalcuSolve on November 21st at Duquesne University. CalcuSolve is a competition that tests students' problem-solving skills related to mathematics. Students compete individually and as part of a group. There were close to 90 teams from school districts in the Pittsburgh area and approximately 300 students who participated in this challenging event. Our 6th graders did an amazing job. Aditya C. tied for 1st individually with a perfect score. Paul D. tied for second individually and Daniel T. tied for third individually. One of Hampton Middle School’s 6th grade teams also took second place as a team. The team members were Rin S., Aditya C., Daniel T., and Paul D.

Fifth and sixth graders from Central, Poff and Wyland also competed in the event. Connor S. tied for second place individually for Grades 5/6. He is a 5th grade student at Central.

Way to go Hampton!
